p.s: In the following I am going to analyze Shylock, the Jewish money-lendermoneylender.
Shylock is a wealthy man living in Venice.
He is not very respected by a lot of people in Venice, since he is a jewJew among a lot of Christians.
Shylock is a father of his daughter Jessica, who ran away with a Christian and had a wife named Leah, who passed away.
In the beginning of the extract Shylock appearesappears to be a good father worrying about his daughter since he even sent his friend Tubal off to look for her.
This first impression however changes quickly when complaining about loosinglosing a lot of money and jewels.
Shylock then adds that he wishes his daughter were dead at his foot and the jewels in her aer!Would she were hearsed at my foot, and the ducats in her coffin... in lines 5 to 7.
This shows that Shylock cares more about the money than his own daughter.
He would not mind if she were dead if that would bring back his lost treasures.
Shylockapprearesappears to be very greedy in this extract which is underlined by stylistic devices.
In line 5 he calls the treasures he lost precious, precious jewels underlining how much he cares about them by saying precious twice.
He does the same when talking about the amount of money he has lost saying two thousand ducats twice.

Shylock also has a lot of self-pity when saying no satisfaction, no revenge: nor no in luck stirring but what lights on my shoulders; no sighs but of my breathing; no tears but of my shedding in lines 8-10.
Since self-pity is often not liked this makes Shylock seem even less sympathetic.
Another trait of Shylock is that he is very mean and wishes bad things for other people.
When Tubal tells him that Antonio has had bad luck, Shylock gets very excited What, what, what?Ill luck, ill luck? (l. 12).
He completely forgets about his own problems and wishes the worst for Antonio.
He even thanks god when hearing about Antonio's problem.
Here again he says all the things twice, which agin underlines what he is saying.
Tubal then goes on telling about Jessica who had spent fourscore ducats in one night.
Again Shylock gets very angry, again showing how greedy he is and that the only thing he cares about is money.
Another time you can see how mean Shylock is, is in line 22.
After finding out that Antonio is ruined, Shylock says I am very glad of it: I'll plague him, I'll torture him: I am glad of it.
Again Shylock is repeating himself which underlines how much he enjoys other people having problems and being able to hurt them.
Shylock is clearly looking forward to hurting Antonio which makes him appear as a very unpleasant man.
All in all Shylock is portrayed as a very mean guy.
He seems to be a terrible father who doesn't care about the wellbeing of his daughter but only wants her back so that she doesn't stay with the Christian man.
He cares more about material thins like money and jewels than his daughter and would not care about her death if that would bring back his goods.
Shylock is a very greedy man who cannot wait to hurt Antonio.
